TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , CARDINAL and DATE respectively and live in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the trial court ” ) convicted the applicants of drug trafficking and sentenced them to CARDINAL , DATE and DATE imprisonment respectively . The trial court established that on DATE , a certain PERSON ( the last name of Mr GPE , as established in the course of the domestic proceedings , later referred to as PERSON ORG ) and the third applicant had arrived at the first applicant 's house where she lived with the second applicant , her stepson . The applicants bought CARDINAL g of heroin from N. for MONEY ( ORG ) . After keeping some drugs back at the house , the applicants divided the remaining CARDINAL g into CARDINAL packs to sell to PERSON ORG , an unidentified end buyer whom they had arranged to meet in a car park near ORG . The second applicant hired a taxi and the remaining applicants took ORG 's car to meet Mr PERSON The police stopped the cars and found the drugs in the taxi . N. escaped . The trial court established these facts on the basis , inter alia , of the statements of the second and third applicants given in the pre - trial proceedings . The court also referred to the first and third applicants ' statements at the hearing , notably that they had been victims of a constructed scenario and that they had not known ORG before the date when the offence was committed , but disregarded them as self - serving . The testimonies of CARDINAL witnesses , as well as items of real evidence , were also taken into account .

CARDINAL . The applicants complained , inter alia , that they had been set up to commit the offence by ORG , an alleged agent provocateur , whom police had allowed to leave the scene . They further complained that no attempt had been made to uncover the truth as regards ORG 's involvement in the commission of the offence .

CARDINAL . At a public session ( јавна седница ) of DATE , in the presence of the public prosecutor , the applicants and their lawyer , ORG dismissed the applicants ' appeal and upheld the trial court 's decision . It stated that efforts to discover ORG 's whereabouts had been unsuccessful . It further argued that the trial court had based its decision on considerable evidence which , taken as a whole , had confirmed the applicants ' involvement in the commission of the crime .

CARDINAL . The trial court sent this decision to the applicants by mail . A stamp “ PERSON ” of DATE was affixed on the post slip returned to the trial court . According to the Government , this stamp was affixed by the detention centre where the applicants were being detained pending the proceedings in question . According to CARDINAL other return receipts bearing the detention centre 's receipt stamp , this decision was received by the latter on DATE . Each applicant signed and dated these receipts : the first applicant received the decision on DATE , the second applicant on DATE and the third on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged an appeal on points of law with ORG . They set out its general basis in a succinct manner and stated that detailed submissions would follow .

CARDINAL . In submissions of CARDINAL DATE , the applicants provided full factual and legal grounds of appeal . They complained , inter alia , of having been entrapped into committing the offence by ORG , whose real name was Mr GPE They provided his whereabouts and stated that he had been actively involved in the crime and had operated as an agent provocateur , under the guidance of the police , who had sent him to incite the second applicant to buy the drugs , given his previous criminal record in that respect . They further maintained that Mr ORG had cooperated with the police in other cases , setting up other people in order to help his cousin who was serving a prison sentence for drug trafficking . The police 's involvement in the crime was supported , inter alia , by the following : they had allowed Mr GPE and PERSON , the unidentified end buyer , to leave the scene at the time of the applicants ' arrest ; the drugs had not been found in a routine police check , but on the basis of advance information about their whereabouts ; and CARDINAL detectives with known identities had been present at the scene . They further complained that the courts had failed to take evidence from these CARDINAL detectives and other police officers who had been present at the scene . The applicants made reference to the ORG 's case - law on the impact of an agent provocateur on convicts ' rights under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected ( отфрла ) the appeal on points of law as out of time . It did so after it had obtained submissions from the public prosecutor in which the latter had requested that the appeal be dismissed on the merits . The court established that ORG decision had been served on the applicants on DATE .

CARDINAL . In submissions of CARDINAL and DATE respectively , the applicants asked ORG to rectify the error in respect of the date of service of ORG decision . In support of their request they submitted a copy of the return receipts bearing the detention centre 's receipt stamp and their signatures ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . This request remained unanswered .

CARDINAL . NORP Under LAW of LAW , it is neither the date of service of the judgment , nor the date of the event , that is taken to be the date from which the time - limit starts to run . It is DATE that is taken as the starting date for calculation of the time - limit . If DATE of the time - limit falls on DATE , DATE or DATE , the time - limit expires at DATE .
